p: H. abyssinica was recently collected in Kenya at Mt. Kasigau. Its local name is “tuka”, and the local community uses it as a source of food ( Figure 1). In Kenya, Hydnora species are found in Kakamega, Mbololo, Mwakitau, Kishushe, Sisera, Ronge, Chyulu Hills, Arabuko Sokoke, Galole (Tana River), Mau, Baringo South, Maungu (Tsavo), and Narok (Rift Valley).
